benchmark_details.name: XGUARD (A Graded Benchmark for Evaluating Safety Failures of Large Language Models on Extremist Content)
benchmark_details.overview: XGUARD is a benchmark and evaluation framework designed to assess the severity of extremist content generated by LLMs. It categorizes model outputs into five danger levels (0â€“4), enabling a more nuanced analysis of both the frequency and severity of failures, using 3,840 red-teaming prompts sourced from real-world data.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a graded assessment framework for extremist content generated by LLMs, allowing for better understanding of model vulnerabilities and defense mechanisms.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dataset relies on semi-template prompt generation, which may not fully capture the complexity and variability of real user inputs.

data.source: 3,840 red-teaming prompts sourced from real-world data such as social media and news.
data.annotation: Manual annotation by experts to categorize responses into five danger levels.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on the proportion of prompts that successfully elicited extremist content and the accuracy of categorization.
methodology.interpretation: Higher scores in ASR indicate more frequent generation of extremist content, while CSR reflects the effectiveness of content classification.
methodology.baseline_results: ASR and CSR metrics were derived from evaluations of six popular LLMs.
methodology.validation: Manual human validation was performed to ensure the reliability of the dataset and evaluative metrics.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The dataset includes diverse prompts aimed at evaluating different forms of extremist texts.
targeted_risks.harm: The potential harm includes the dissemination of extremist narratives that could incite violence or promote radicalization.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: Licensed for academic research; commercial use is not permitted.
